thread.title: Ravensthorpe cut off by floodwater, chopper sent to rescue stranded drivers
thread.title_full: Ravensthorpe cut off by floodwater, chopper sent to rescue stranded drivers

title: Ravensthorpe cut off by floodwater, chopper sent to rescue stranded drivers
text:
Map: Ravensthorpe 6346 
A helicopter has rescuedabout 15 people trapped by floodwaters on Western Australia's south coast. 
The group had been travelling in six cars, but is understood to have become cut off between Jerramungup and Ravensthorpe. 
Ravensthorpe has been completely cut off and the Phillips River Bridge, on the South Coast Highway west to Albany, has been entirely washed away. 
The Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES) said it had sent a helicopter to winch the group to safety. 
The Shire of Ravensthorpe has offered to house them for the night. 
DFES Duty Chief Superintendent Rob Cox said the group had done nothing wrong. 
"They didn't go through a road closure, they just got trapped in between the floodways," he said. External Link: Facebook video: Great Southern District WA police post video of floodwaters. 
Photographs showed all remnants of the Phillips River Bridge had vanished, pushed downstream by a huge torrent of water. 
"It was built to last this time, but it's completely gone now, so that cuts off access to Albany," Ravensthorpe Shire Councillor Kerry Dickinson said. 
"[It's] washed away. A large chunk of it's gone." 
Ravensthorpe police said on Twitter the town was cut off in every direction. 
Water had also blocked the roads east to Esperance, south to the coastal town of Hopetoun and north to Lake King. 
Police said multiple vehicles were stranded in the area and they were warning people not to drive in or out of the area. 
Councillor Dickinson said the power was still connected in Ravensthorpe and the shire had enough back-up generators to act as an auxiliary power station if needed. 
She said the downpour had not stopped since Tuesday evening.
